Some clarification here. Heller never adopted a "reasonable regulation" standard.    Color of Law 
 U.S. law enforcement officers and other officials like judges, prosecutors, and security guards have been given tremendous power by local, state, and federal government agencies—authority they must have to enforce the law and ensure justice in our country. These powers include the authority to detain and arrest suspects, to search and seize property, to bring criminal charges, to make rulings in court, and to use deadly force in certain situations. 
 
 Preventing abuse of this authority, however, is equally necessary to the health of our nation’s democracy. That’s why it’s a federal crime for anyone acting under “color of law” willfully to deprive or conspire to deprive a person of a right protected by the Constitution or U.S. law. “Color of law” simply means that the person is using authority given to him or her by a local, state, or federal government agency.

It IS most common for Mr. or Mrs. Smith to assume that someone wearing a sidearm is a cop, off-duty or whatever. Police know better, and I think they recognize the goatee as not police-issue. I agree that the police shouldn't assume anything. They especially shouldn't assume that someone wearing a sidearm is breaking or about to break the law(s). In fact, the Michigan AG says that the carrying of a holstered firearm alone doesn't constitute RAS (reasonably articulated suspicion) or PC (probable cause) for a terry stop. The criminal element just doesn't openly carry. That may change as more civi's start OCing but as of now, that's the way it is (and should stay).
 
 From experience, I'll tell you the most common reactions to OC: 1st most common reaction is none at all. You'd be surprised to know just how many people don't even notice it. The 2nd most common reaction is the assumption that the OCer is an LEO. Lastly, you're recognized as a civi who's enjoying the RTKBA. I've recieved nods from LEOs, no more and no less. I was once stopped and thanked for "what I do" by an elderly woman. I told her "I'm not a policeman" and she replied with "Oh. Well thank you for making me feel safe anyway"... which was followed up by a nice conversation about OC.
 
 I'd never want an LEO to "let his guard down" around someone who's visibly carrying or at any other time. An LEO should be just as alert to an open carrier as he would be to someone who might be concealing. Just because you don't see a gun on someone doesn't mean it's not there. In a sense, an LEO might be little more concerned with someone who he doesn't see a firearm on, since the display of an openly carried gun is somewhat indicative that the person carrying it doesn't have anything to hide.
